commit_message:
Add Non-Trivial-Solution Constraint to the Solver Scheduler

This linear constraint forces each instance to be placed at
exactly one host. This should normally be enabled
to avoid non-trivial solution from the solver.

Partially implements: blueprint solver-scheduler

Change-Id: I7aba2a408046211cbd6f5ca7d16310ef9bbc4c0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/70/74270/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Cisco Systems Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova.openstack.common import log as logging from nova.scheduler.solvers import linearconstraints LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class OneHostPerInstanceConstraint(linearconstraints.BaseLinearConstraint): """ Constraint that forces each instance to be placed at exactly one host. """ # The linear constraint should be formed as: # coeff_matrix * var_matrix' (operator) (constants) # where (operator) is ==, >, >=, <, <=, !=, etc. # For convenience, the (constants) is merged into left-hand-side, # thus the right-hand-side is 0. def __init__(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): [self.num_hosts, self.num_instances] = self._get_host_instance_nums( hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec) def _get_host_instance_nums(self, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec): """This method calculates number of hosts and instances.""" num_hosts = len(hosts) if instance_uuids: num_instances = len(instance_uuids) else: num_instances = request_spec.get('num_instances', 1) return [num_hosts,num_instances] def get_coefficient_matrix(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): # The coefficient for each variable is 1 and # constant in each constraint is (-1). coefficient_matrix = [[1 for i in range(self.num_hosts)] + [-1] for j in range(self.num_instances)] return coefficient_matrix def get_variable_matrix(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): # The variable_matrix[i,j] denotes the relationship between # instance[i] and host[j] variable_matrix = [] variable_matrix = [[variables[i][j] for i in range(self.num_hosts)] + [1] for j in range(self.num_instances)] return variable_matrix def get_operations(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): # Operations are '=='. operations = [(lambda x: x == 0) for j in range(self.num_instances)] return operations

commit_message:
Adding the Availability Zone constraint

This constraint ensures only hosts in the specified availability zone are selected.

Partially implements: blueprint solver-scheduler

Change-Id: I22b8488548d95b21d9f63e187b19afb42d311726
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/77/74277/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Cisco Systems Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo.config import cfg from nova.compute import api as compute from nova import db from nova.openstack.common import log as logging from nova.scheduler.solvers import linearconstraints LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CONF = cfg.CONF CONF.import_opt('default_availability_zone', 'nova.availability_zones') class AvailabilityZoneConstraint(linearconstraints.BaseLinearConstraint): """ To select only the hosts belonging to an availability zone. """ def __init__(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): self.compute_api = compute.API() [self.num_hosts, self.num_instances] = self._get_host_instance_nums( hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec) def _get_host_instance_nums(self, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec): """This method calculates number of hosts and instances.""" num_hosts = len(hosts) if instance_uuids: num_instances = len(instance_uuids) else: num_instances = request_spec.get('num_instances', 1) return [num_hosts, num_instances] # The linear constraint should be formed as: # coeff_matrix * var_matrix' (operator) constant_vector # where (operator) is ==, >, >=, <, <=, !=, etc. # For convenience, the constant_vector is merged into left-hand-side, # thus the right-hand-side is always 0. def get_coefficient_vectors(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): # Coefficients are 0 for hosts in the availability zone, 1 for others spec = filter_properties.get('request_spec', {}) props = spec.get('instance_properties', {}) availability_zone = props.get('availability_zone') coefficient_vectors = [] for host in hosts: if availability_zone: context = filter_properties['context'].elevated() metadata = db.aggregate_metadata_get_by_host(context, host.host, key='availability_zone') if 'availability_zone' in metadata: if availability_zone in metadata['availability_zone']: coefficient_vectors.append([0 for j in range( self.num_instances)]) else: coefficient_vectors.append([1 for j in range( self.num_instances)]) elif availability_zone == CONF.default_availability_zone: coefficient_vectors.append([0 for j in range( self.num_instances)]) else: coefficient_vectors.append([1 for j in range( self.num_instances)]) else: coefficient_vectors.append([0 for j in range( self.num_instances)]) return coefficient_vectors def get_variable_vectors(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): # The variable_vectors[i,j] denotes the relationship between # host[i] and instance[j]. variable_vectors = [] variable_vectors = [[variables[i][j] for j in range( self.num_instances)] for i in range(self.num_hosts)] return variable_vectors def get_operations(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): # Operations are '=='. operations = [(lambda x: x == 0) for i in range(self.num_hosts)] return operations

commit_message:
Add a pluggable LP solver to the solver scheduler

This provides a pluggable LP solver based on PULP for the solver
scheduler, where cost functions and constraints can be plugged-in.
The illustrative implementation of costs and constraints provides
a unified form of cost/constraint plugins for a general LP solver.

Partially implements: blueprint solver-scheduler
DocImpact: Added additional configuration options.

Change-Id: Ic79f4caa48b80bc70a49550acfaa53275e99f566

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Cisco Systems Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Linear constraints for scheduler linear constraint solvers """ from nova import loadables class BaseLinearConstraint(object): """Base class for linear constraint.""" # The linear constraint should be formed as: # coeff_vector * var_vector' <operator> <constants> # where <operator> is ==, >, >=, <, <=, !=, etc. # For convenience, the <constants> can be merged into left-hand-side, # thus the right-hand-side is always 0. def __init__(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): pass def get_coefficient_vectors(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): """Retruns a list of coefficient vectors.""" raise NotImplementedError() def get_variable_vectors(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): """Returns a list of variable vectors.""" raise NotImplementedError() def get_operations(self, variables, hosts, instance_uuids, request_spec, filter_properties): """Returns a list of operations.""" raise NotImplementedError() class LinearConstraintHandler(loadables.BaseLoader): def __init__(self): super(LinearConstraintHandler, self).__init__(BaseLinearConstraint) def all_linear_constraints(): """Return a list of lineear constraint classes found in this directory. This method is used as the default for available linear constraints for scheduler and should return a list of all linearconstraint classes available. """ return LinearConstraintHandler().get_all_classes()

commit_message:
Remove dependent module py3kcompat

Module py3kcompat was removed from oslo-incubator, we can use
six directly.

Change-Id: I4dcff158b59d3d5839a10201552f6a6c144f65fe
Closes-Bug: #1280033

subject: VMware create_virtual_disk refactor
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-16 08:55:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0dc399f2843a7f5557c1ce8279f1bd3039b926be', 'message': 'VMware create_virtual_disk refactor

Several methods are repeating code for creating the virtual disk.
This refactor isolates the code for that task so it can be reused.

We mark the inner method as deprecated because we cannot remove
it in a small patch. That move will require a larger effort.

Related blueprint improve-vmware-disk-usage

Change-Id: I2cda8299fc5315975c5f3c8bc0f5e2a72811a5f9

commit_message:
VMware create_virtual_disk refactor

Several methods are repeating code for creating the virtual disk.
This refactor isolates the code for that task so it can be reused.

Related blueprint improve-vmware-disk-usage
Co-authored-by: Shawn Hartsock <hartsocks@vmware.com>

Change-Id: I2cda8299fc5315975c5f3c8bc0f5e2a72811a5f9

Update sample catalog templates

The sample catalog templates have not been updated recently.
I based the file off of the one in the devstack project.

commit_message:
Replace assertEqual(None, *) with assertIsNone in tests

Replace assertEqual(None, *) with assertIsNone in tests to have
more clear messages in case of failure.

Change-Id: If2c64e55cce3650bc493e4c9ad77a5c497d28a36

commit_message:
VMWare: session management refactor - tools

introduce session diagnostic methods to Vim object.
Start the process of eliminating the need for the
VMwareAPISession object by folding these functions back
into the Vim object and authoring them to use the
vSphere API as intended without wrappers.

We are also using lower privilege methods to manipulate
just our own sessions as opposed to previous versions
which used super-user or administrator level privileges
to manipulate sessions globally.

Change-Id: I6daf8366185fd3768fa75973b6b1c41ac6314fec
blueprint: vmware-soap-session-management

Change-Id: Iea3a232e53c233a7ddf6870043d11fe1408ddab4

Added script for toggable help button

*** In order to make the description block show or hide on
    the click action, there's a new function in InitFunction of
    horizon that handle the events.

Change-Id: I95eaec32c9a0338418a15567feba4d89b76d03a8
Implements: blueprint horizon-modal-help

Added a new tag for passing variable to extends

*** The new tag name is xextends.

*** USE:   {% xextends "base.html" with key=value %}

*** This tag is used for passing a variable which tell the modal
    form to hide/show the help button (used for permanent help text)

Change-Id: If8bdd7032441f621dd3fafe97407453347315f7b
Implements: blueprint horizon-modal-help

Help block can now be persistent

*** By adding the variable persistent_help_text, the help block
    will be shown in all time and there won't be any question mark
    top right.

*** If the modal is not using any tabs, you can add the variable by
    changing the {% extends ... %} by
    {% xextends ... with persistent_help_text %}. If it has any tabs,
    you can add the variable into the class workflows.Workflow.

*** Also, in order to be able to avoid adding the class description and
    show/hide, there is a setup script into horizon.modals.js that handle
    that part.

Change-Id: I53517aab1df4fd1959abb337a6ca81fed14cc762
Implements: blueprint horizon-modal-help
'}]
commit_message:
Added help button for modal forms

*** Help button has the same size/look as the quit button

*** We are currently changing the look n feel of the modal
    forms since we are loosing a great portion of the page for the
    help text which is not always required (also prevent us from making
    the layout horizon). So, we are making the help text toggable.

*** Also for now, only the project/images_and_snapshots page is different.
    All other modals are the same for now.

Implements: blueprint horizon-modal-help
Change-Id: Iea3a232e53c233a7ddf6870043d11fe1408ddab4

Added script for toggable help button

*** In order to make the description block show or hide on
    the click action, there's a new function in InitFunction of
    horizon that handle the events.

Change-Id: I95eaec32c9a0338418a15567feba4d89b76d03a8
Implements: blueprint horizon-modal-help

Added a new tag for passing variable to extends

*** The new tag name is xextends.

*** USE:   {% xextends "base.html" with key=value %}

*** This tag is used for passing a variable which tell the modal
    form to hide/show the help button (used for permanent help text)

Change-Id: If8bdd7032441f621dd3fafe97407453347315f7b
Implements: blueprint horizon-modal-help

Help block can now be persistent

*** By adding the variable persistent_help_text, the help block
    will be shown in all time and there won't be any question mark
    top right.

*** If the modal is not using any tabs, you can add the variable by
    changing the {% extends ... %} by
    {% xextends ... with persistent_help_text %}. If it has any tabs,
    you can add the variable into the class workflows.Workflow.

*** Also, in order to be able to avoid adding the class description and
    show/hide, there is a setup script into horizon.modals.js that handle
    that part.

Change-Id: I53517aab1df4fd1959abb337a6ca81fed14cc762
Implements: blueprint horizon-modal-help
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/40/76940/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // setup help block // by doing it this way, we don't need to modify all pages with a modal box var numberElement = $('#modal_wrapper').find(".modal-header").children().length; var elementHelp; // verify if it's a tabs modal... if ($('#modal_wrapper').find(".tab-content").length > 0) { elementHelp = $('#modal_wrapper').find(".help_text"); } else { elementHelp = $('#modal_wrapper').find(".right:first"); } var elementForms = elementHelp.prev(); if (numberElement == 2) { // permanent help box... elementHelp.addClass('description show'); elementForms.css("border-right", "rgb(240,240,240) solid thin"); } else { elementHelp.addClass('description hide'); } $('#modal_wrapper').find(".modal-body").css("padding", "0px"); var formElement = descriptionElement.prev(); formElement.css("border-right", "rgb(240,240,240) solid thin"); formElement.css("border-right", "");

commit_message:
Add testing of migrations from oslo

There is a testing of migrations in oslo.
We can check equality of models with migrations in different
backends. Also we can check an each migration in full mode
(upgrade > downgrade > upgrade).
We should have both of these tests for successfull checking of
migrations.

Dependences: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/42307/

bp: db-common-migration-and-utils

Change-Id: Id5864b14b0c567e218ba3622f154c4841907fdc4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/03/55503/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Ensure only add task/flows to flows

To avoid mistakes where classes are added
or where non-task or non-flow items are added
to a flow, just raise an exception when this
add is attempted in the first place.

Change-Id: I406daad5c6c74ed2649747f50c632b7159c357ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/56/78056/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from taskflow import task if not isinstance(item, (flow.Flow, task.BaseTask)): raise exc.InvariantViolation( "%(item)s is not an instance" " of a flow or a task, and adding %(item_type)s" " is disallowed" % dict(item=item, item_type=type(item)))

commit_message:
Adding 'enable_dhcp' field to network_data.

Expose 'enable_dhcp' field as part of the network_data information of
metadata service. Information about dhcp is available from the neutronv2
'get port' call. This is mapped to be part of the fixed ip data in the
result.

The network data is available at
GET: http://169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/network_data

DocImpact

Partial implements: blueprint metadata-service-network-info

Change-Id: I1db3151a3183bc59aad90858083aa652b66c600c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/04/77504/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'ip_version': 4, 'enable_dhcp': True}

commit_message:
Adding more datastore version tests

Change-Id: I92a3cfbbacfa7cfbfd85db303e61fa28b5ccddb8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/41/76041/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @test def test_create_failure_with_datastore_id_and_invalid_version_id(self): if VOLUME_SUPPORT: volume = {'size': 1} else: volume = None instance_name = "datastore_version_notfound" databases = [] users = [] datastore = CONFIG.dbaas_datastore_id datastore_version_id = "z00000z0-00z0-0z00-00z0-000z000000zz" try: assert_raises(exceptions.NotFound, dbaas.instances.create, instance_name, instance_info.dbaas_flavor_href, volume, databases, users, datastore=datastore, datastore_version=datastore_version_id) except exceptions.BadRequest as e: assert_equal(e.message, "Datastore version '%s' cannot be found." % datastore_version_id) @test(depends_on_classes=[InstanceSetup], run_after_class=[CreateInstanceFail], groups=[GROUP, GROUP_START, GROUP_START_SIMPLE, tests.INSTANCES], runs_after_groups=[tests.PRE_INSTANCES, 'dbaas_quotas']) class CreateInstanceDatastoreAttributes(object): """Test to create a Database Instance Specifying a mixture of datastore type and version values. """ @test def test_create_with_datastore_type_and_version_combos(self): def _result_is_active(): instance = dbaas.instances.get(instance_info.id) if instance.status == "ACTIVE": return True else: # If it's not ACTIVE, anything but BUILD must be # an error. assert_equal("BUILD", instance.status) return False def _result_is_not_found(): try: dbaas.instances.get(instance_info.id) except exceptions.NotFound as e: assert_equal(e.message, "Resource %s cannot be found" % instance_info.id) return True report = CONFIG.get_report() databases = [] databases.append({"name": "firstdb", "character_set": "latin2", "collate": "latin2_general_ci"}) databases.append({"name": "db2"}) instance_info.databases = databases users = [] users.append({"name": "lite", "password": "litepass", "databases": [{"name": "firstdb"}]}) instance_info.users = users if VOLUME_SUPPORT: instance_info.volume = {'size': 1} else: instance_info.volume = None ds_ver = [None, CONFIG.dbaas_datastore_version, CONFIG.dbaas_datastore_version_id] ds_type = [CONFIG.dbaas_datastore, CONFIG.dbaas_datastore_id] for version in ds_ver: for name in ds_type: instance_info.initial_result = dbaas.instances.create( instance_info.name, instance_info.dbaas_flavor_href, instance_info.volume, databases, users, availability_zone="nova", datastore=name, datastore_version=version) assert_equal(200, dbaas.last_http_code) result = instance_info.initial_result instance_info.id = result.id instance_info.dbaas_datastore_version = \ result.datastore['version'] instance_info.dbaas_datastore = result.datastore['type'] report.log("Instance UUID = %s" % instance_info.id) assert_equal("BUILD", instance_info.initial_result.status) poll_until(_result_is_active) details = dbaas.instances.get(instance_info.id) assert_equal(200, dbaas.last_http_code) assert_equal(instance_info.dbaas_datastore, details.datastore['type']) assert_equal(instance_info.dbaas_datastore_version, details.datastore['version']) dbaas.instances.delete(instance_info.id) assert_equal(202, dbaas.last_http_code) poll_until(_result_is_not_found)

commit_message:
Fix the parameter order of assertEqual in novaclient test

On assertEqual, the order of parameters should be (expected, observed).
But, some part of novaclient test were written with invalid order.
This patch fixes this problem.

Change-Id: I1c7cbdffa25d8d1e6803c36334b64b4fb5a35772
Partially-bug: #1277104

commit_message:
check the header's encoding of the request

Check the HTTP headers in the request which accesses to account or
container if they contianer non-unicoded messages and return a
bad request response

Change-Id: I24f696fd0a1b695021e3d2a913c67046dc205375
Closes-Bug: #1244613

commit_message:
Collapse some error handling in rabbit ensure()

Rather than having 3 separate except blocks doing the
same work to handle errors, catch all of the exceptions
in one place and do the work once.

Change-Id: I21a8ac56eb7df96d14bc00d72ae4e8d69564e2f2

commit_message:
SSH login to openstack server using proxy

This commit add support for SSH login to openstack instances, using a proxy
server. It also include unit tests.

The following tokens are exposed in tempest configuration file:
    1. ssh_proxy -- true/false. login to openstack instance through proxy
    2. ssh_proxy_host -- proxy host name
    3. ssh_proxy_user -- user name to login to proxy host
    4. ssh_proxy_key -- private key to use to login to proxy host

Closes-Bug: 1246019
Change-Id: Idda7812f779530a07b29e5e0f87e0ecf358b8dfb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/98/69298/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class SSHProxyError(TempestException): message = ("Authentication to SSH Proxy server failed.\n" "Proxy host: %(host)s, User: %(user)s, Key: %(key)s")

commit_message:
Provide doc for a Trove development workflow

Change-Id: Ib6f3a7055b71b9598e37a3e84e10233e593f2d27
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/29/70629/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TODO In order to contribute to Trove, you must complete these steps first. ============ Introduction ============ This document proposes a workflow for developing on Trove using RedStack. In this proposal, git acts as a mechanism for pushing changes to a RedStack VM and additionally as a mechanism to trigger restarts of the processes affected by the push. This includes ``trove-api``, ``trove-taskmanager``, ``trove-conductor``, and ``trove-guestagent``. When everything is set up, a test deployment (including process restarts) to a RedStack VM should be as simple as:: # on your laptop $ git push test Here's an overview: TODO <image here> These instructions involve two machines: a RedStack VM and your laptop (or wherever you plan on coding). Be sure to use the section or command-level comments to know on which machine the command is to be run. ================= RedStack VM Setup ================= All commands in this section are to be run on the RedStack VM. 1. Create an Ubuntu 12.04 (Precise Pangolin) VM having user ``ubuntu`` with key-based SSH login from laptop (not shown). 2. Install git:: $ sudo apt-get update $ sudo apt-get -y install git-core 3. Set up a bare git repository by cloning the official Trove repo. (The bare repository will receive pushes from your laptop. It will also be cloned into ``/opt/stack/trove``.):: $ mkdir ~/gitrepos $ git clone --bare git://git.openstack.org/openstack/trove.git ~/gitrepos/trove.git 4. Download RedStack helper functions. These functions make it easier to stop and start the Trove services as well as pull code for updating the guest agent. The functions appear in the appendix below. 5. Setup ``post-receive`` hook on the bare repo. This will run after a push to the bare repo. It will update ``/opt/stack/trove`` and restart the Trove services:: $ cat <<"EOF" > ~/gitrepos/trove.git/hooks/post-receive #!/bin/bash cd `dirname $0` DIR=`pwd` set -e set -x # optionally set GUEST_IP (defaults to 10.0.0.2) # GUEST_IP=10.0.0.3 source $DIR/redstack-helpers.sh backup_guestagent_conf echo "Updating /opt/stack/trove..." git --git-dir=/opt/stack/trove/.git --work-tree=/opt/stack/trove fetch git --git-dir=/opt/stack/trove/.git --work-tree=/opt/stack/trove reset --hard origin/master restore_guestagent_conf restart_tr_api restart_tr_tmgr restart_tr_cond echo "Pulling code onto guest ($GUEST_IP)..." update_guest_code EOF $ chmod +x ~/gitrepos/trove.git/hooks/post-receive 6. Do some preliminary work so that RedStack will use our custom Trove repo instead of the official Trove repo. By pre-creating ``/opt/stack/trove``, RedStack will not touch it:: $ git clone https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack.git ~/devstack $ echo "TROVE_REPO=$HOME/gitrepos/trove.git" >> ~/devstack/localrc $ sudo mkdir -p /opt/stack $ sudo chown `whoami` /opt/stack $ git clone ~/gitrepos/trove.git /opt/stack/trove 7. Install RedStack:: $ git clone git://git.openstack.org/openstack/trove-integration.git ~/trove-integration $ cd ~/trove-integration/scripts/ $ ./redstack install 8. Fix libvirtd logrotate config. (It rotates far too infrequently and can fill up the VM's disk.):: $ if ! grep " size" /etc/logrotate.d/libvirtd; then sudo sed -i 's/}/ size 50M\n}/g' /etc/logrotate.d/libvirtd; fi 9. Build and install MySQL image:: $ ./redstack kick-start mysql 10. Setup a nested guest (adjust commands to create a nested guest using the desired datastore):: $ source ~/devstack/openrc demo demo $ trove create guest 2 --size 1 $ while ! trove list | grep " guest .* ACTIVE "; do sleep 10; done ============================= Development Environment Setup ============================= All commands in this section are to be run on your laptop. 1. Clone Trove repo:: $ git clone git://git.openstack.org/openstack/trove.git 2. Configure your project to know about Gerrit:: $ git review --setup 3. Setup remote ``test`` and refspec so you only need to run ``git push test`` without any other argumentss to copy changes to your RedStack VM. All local branches will be pushed to ``test/master``. Furthermore, all pushes will overwrite ``test/master`` even if not a fast-forward. This is OK as you will be the only one pushing there. Always using ``master`` keeps the DevStack configuration simple:: $ cd trove $ git remote add test `whoami`@$vm:/home/`whoami`/gitrepos/trove.git $ git config remote.test.push +HEAD:refs/heads/master 4. Do rebase rather than merge when pulling:: $ git config pull.rebase true 5. Create a branch for your change and check it out (see branch naming conventions):: $ git fetch origin $ git checkout -b BRANCHNAME --track origin/master 6. Make a change. Here are some examples. a) Add your own log message to ``trove/instance/service.py:InstanceController.index()`` and save the file. Trigger this log message with ``trove list`` and check ``trove-api`` stdout (refer to DevStack documentation for checking stdout of processes):: def index(self, req, tenant_id): ... LOG.info(_("Indexing a database instance for tenant '%s'") % tenant_id) LOG.info(_("testing!!!")) # new log line b) Add your own log message to ``trove/guestagent/datastore/mysql/service.py:MySqlAppStatus._get_actual_db_status()`` and save the file. Trigger this log message simply by running ``sudo service trove-guest restart`` and checking ``/tmp/logfile.txt`` (both on the nested guest):: def _get_actual_db_status(self): ... LOG.info("Service Status is RUNNING.") LOG.info("testing!!!") # new log line 7. Run ``tox``. See Testing section below. 8. Commit your changes. See commit message conventions. 9. Rebase from official Trove repo often:: $ git pull 10. Push your changes to your VM. This pushes your current branch to the ``master`` branch on the bare repo:: $ git push test 11. You will likely need to commit multiple times while working. Before submitting to Gerrit, these commits will need to be combined. There are two ways to solve this problem: a) Don't create multiple commits in the first place. Create the initial commit and then amend it with changes. This approach is best used for a commit message modification or the addition of a missed file:: $ git commit --amend b) Squash multiple commits using interactive rebase. Of the two approaches, this one is probably safer as the lineage of commits stays reachable from ``HEAD``. If you break something, you can just compare to the last commit:: $ git rebase -i 12. At this point, you can submit to Gerrit (one last rebase is recommended prior to running this command):: $ git review ======== Testing ======== ----------------- Introduction ----------------- Tests (of various types) are present in both the ``trove`` project and the ``trove-integration`` project. This page breaks the tests down via project. Project: trove ============== All tests (of any type) in the ``trove`` project can be run using the ``tox`` command. Prerequisites ------------- 1. You must install the ``tox`` tool:: $ sudo pip install tox 2. You need to install MySQL since one of the Python modules requires the ``mysql_config`` binary. Note that MySQL Server does not need to be running. a) For Ubuntu:: $ sudo apt-get install libmysqlclient-dev b) For OS X: (i) Go to the Download MySQL Community Server page. (ii) Download and install. (iii) Add ``/usr/local/mysql/bin`` to your PATH. tox -------- ``tox`` is a general-purpose tool for running commands inside virtual environments. In the case of the ``trove`` project, ``tox`` is instructed to run the commands below for the environments named ``py26`` and ``py27`` (see ``tox.ini`` in the ``trove`` project):: {envpython} run_tests.py {envpython} run_tests.py --test-config=etc/tests/xml.localhost.test.conf python setup.py testr --slowest Lines 1 and 2 run integration tests with fake mode enabled. Line 3 runs unit tests. TODO Explain diff between above two ``run_tests.py`` commands. Unit Tests ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A command called ``testr`` from ``testrepository`` runs the unit tests (``trove.tests.unittests``). From ``testrepository`` documentation, "This will first list the tests, partition the tests into one partition per CPU on the machine, and then invoke multiple test runners at the same time, with each test runner getting one partition." Note that each worker is a separate process with its own memory and therefore tests can safely modify shared objects (e.g. ``oslo.config.cfg.ConfigOpts``) during a test. (Of course you still need to reset the object state back before moving on to the next test as you would normally.) But ``testr`` is also part of the larger ``tox`` run as described above. See ``.testr.conf`` in the ``trove`` project. 1. Run ``tox``. The first time you run this, runtime and test dependencies will be installed first inside a virtualenv. Later runs will simply run the tests in this populated virtualenv:: $ cd trove $ tox -epy27 -epep8 You can run ``testr`` by itself (i.e. just run the unit tests) after you have run ``tox`` at least once. 1. Run something similar to the following (change virtual environment if you want):: $ cd trove $ source/.tox/py27/bin/activate $ python setup.py testr # add --slowest if you want $ deactivate Integration Tests ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ A command called ``run_tests.py`` runs the integration tests (`trove.tests.api`). But this is also part of the larger ``tox`` run as described above. ``run_tests.py`` enables "fake mode." Note: Some integration tests in the ``trove`` project can run in either fake mode or real mode. 1. Run ``tox``. The first time you run this, runtime and test dependencies will be installed first inside a virtualenv. Later runs will simply run the tests in this populated virtualenv:: $ cd trove $ tox -epy27 -epep8 Fake Mode +++++++++ TODO wsgi intercept, etc Cleanup and re-running tox after git rebase ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 1. Delete ``trove/.testrepository`` 2. Delete ``trove/.tox`` 3. Delete ``trove/.venv`` 4. Re-run ``tox`` Project: trove-integration ============================= The ``trove-integration`` project runs a superset of the integration tests (it imports some modules from the ``trove`` project plus adds some of its own), this time in "real mode." In other words, real RedStack-started services are used:: $ ./redstack int-tests ======== Appendix ======== RedStack helper functions:: NL=`echo -ne '\015'` GUEST_IP=${GUEST_IP:-10.0.0.2} GUEST_USERNAME=${GUEST_USERNAME:-`whoami`} function send_stuff { local name=$1 local stuff=$2 screen -S stack -p "$name" -X stuff "$stuff" } function send_sigint { local name=$1 send_stuff "$name" $'\003' } function proc_count { local search="$1" pgrep -fc "$1" } function stop_tr_api { local procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-api" || true` if [ "$procs" == "0" ]; then echo "trove-api already stopped" return 0 fi send_sigint "tr-api" sleep 2 procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-api" || true` if [ "$procs" != "0" ]; then echo "trove-api didn't stop" return 1 fi echo "trove-api stopped" } function stop_tr_tmgr { local procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-taskmanager" || true` if [ "$procs" == "0" ]; then echo "trove-taskmanager already stopped" return 0 fi send_sigint "tr-tmgr" sleep 2 procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-taskmanager" || true` if [ "$procs" != "0" ]; then echo "trove-taskmanager didn't stop" return 1 fi echo "trove-taskmanager stopped" } function stop_tr_cond { local procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-conductor" || true` if [ "$procs" == "0" ]; then echo "trove-conductor already stopped" return 0 fi send_sigint "tr-cond" sleep 2 procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-conductor" || true` if [ "$procs" != "0" ]; then echo "trove-conductor didn't stop" return 1 fi echo "trove-conductor stopped" } function start_tr_api { local procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-api" || true` if [ "$procs" != "0" ]; then echo "trove-api already started" return 0 fi send_stuff "tr-api" "cd /opt/stack/trove; bin/trove-api --config-file=/etc/trove/trove.conf --debug 2>&1 $NL" sleep 2 procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-api" || true` if [ "$procs" == "0" ]; then echo "trove-api didn't start" return 1 fi echo "trove-api started" } function start_tr_tmgr { local procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-taskmanager" || true` if [ "$procs" != "0" ]; then echo "trove-taskmanager already started" return 0 fi send_stuff "tr-tmgr" "cd /opt/stack/trove; bin/trove-taskmanager --config-file=/etc/trove/trove-taskmanager.conf --debug 2>&1 $NL" sleep 2 procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-taskmanager" || true` if [ "$procs" == "0" ]; then echo "trove-taskmanager didn't start" return 1 fi echo "trove-taskmanager started" } function start_tr_cond { local procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-conductor" || true` if [ "$procs" != "0" ]; then echo "trove-conductor already started" return 0 fi send_stuff "tr-cond" "cd /opt/stack/trove; bin/trove-conductor --config-file=/etc/trove/trove-conductor.conf --debug 2>&1 $NL" sleep 2 procs=`proc_count "python bin/trove-conductor" || true` if [ "$procs" == "0" ]; then echo "trove-conductor didn't stop" return 1 fi echo "trove-conductor started" } function restart_tr_api { stop_tr_api start_tr_api } function restart_tr_tmgr { stop_tr_tmgr start_tr_tmgr } function restart_tr_cond { stop_tr_cond start_tr_cond } function do_in_guest { local cmd=$1 ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no $GUEST_USERNAME@$GUEST_IP "$cmd" } function start_tr_guest { do_in_guest "sudo service trove-guest start" } function stop_tr_guest { do_in_guest "sudo service trove-guest stop" } function restart_tr_guest { do_in_guest "sudo service trove-guest restart" } function update_guest_code { do_in_guest "sudo -u $GUEST_USERNAME rsync -e 'ssh -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no' -avz --exclude='.*' ${GUEST_USERNAME}@10.0.0.1:/opt/stack/trove/ /home/$GUEST_USERNAME/trove && sudo service trove-guest restart" } function backup_guestagent_conf { if [ ! -f /etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf.sample ]; then sudo cp -p /opt/stack/trove/etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf.sample /etc/trove fi } function restore_guestagent_conf { sudo cp -p /etc/trove/trove-guestagent.conf.sample /opt/stack/trove/etc/trove }

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.network import base from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest import clients from tempest import exceptions from tempest.test import attr class AuthorizationTestJSON(base.BaseNetworkTest): _interface = 'json' @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(AuthorizationTestJSON, cls).setUpClass() cls.network = cls.create_network() cls.alt_manager = clients.AltManager() cls.alt_client = cls.alt_manager.network_client cls.adm_manager = clients.AdminManager() cls.identity_client = cls.adm_manager.identity_v3_client @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_create_network_for_alt_account_fails(self): # A create network request should fail if the tenant id does not match # the current user name = data_utils.rand_name('network-') resp, project = self.identity_client.create_project( data_utils.rand_name('project-new')) self.assertRaises(exceptions.BadRequest, self.client.create_network, name=name, tenant_id=project['id']) self.identity_client.delete_project(project['id']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_create_shared_network_by_unauthorized_user(self): # A create shared network request should fail if the current user isn't # granted admin_role name = data_utils.rand_name('network-') self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, self.client.create_network, name=name, shared=1) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_delete_network_of_alt_account_fails(self): # A delete network request for another user should fail self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.alt_client.delete_network, self.network['id']) @attr(type=['negative', 'gate']) def test_create_port_in_network_of_another_user_fails(self): # A create port request in another user's network should fail self.assertRaises(exceptions.NotFound, self.alt_client.create_port, network_id=self.network['id']) class AuthorizationTestXML(AuthorizationTestJSON): _interface = 'xml'

subject: Deploy VMware vCenter templates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-06-28 15:40:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/77a75f97e7c420a72ed09db612a5e2f868217096', 'message': 'Deploy vCenter templates

VMware vCenter already has the deployable images in the form of
Templates. Therefore to enable the deployment of these templates
the glance image corresponding to the template contains only
the meta-data of the template. This meta-data includes
a. IP of the vcenter where the template is present. This is
   required since the scope of a template is a single vcenter.

b. The name of the template. To simplify initial implementation,
   the name of the image is expected to match the template name.

The nova driver also publishes the vcenter ip in its capabilities
in the supported_instances attribute.
When a nova boot is done, the driver determines if the image is a
template by inspecting the meta-data and uses the vcenter SDK
to deploy if the image is a template.

Change-Id: I967b1de30527cef8953fe8d3f3e2448f91fa60a6
Blueprint: deploy-vcenter-templates-from-vmware-nova-driver

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2013-09-02 18:49:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c011baf44fc6dd9a3238e6887c78d291399c9866', 'message': 'Deploy vCenter templates

VMware vCenter already has the deployable images in the form of
Templates. Therefore to enable the deployment of these templates
the glance image corresponding to the template contains meta-data
of the template (if it exists).
This meta-data includes the name of the template (template_name).
When a nova boot is done, the driver determines if the image is a
template by inspecting the meta-data and uses the vcenter SDK
to deploy if the image is a template. If a template does not exist
then the image will be used to create the VM.

Change-Id: I967b1de30527cef8953fe8d3f3e2448f91fa60a6
Blueprint: deploy-vcenter-templates-from-vmware-nova-driver

commit_message:
Deploy VMware vCenter templates

VMware vCenter already has the deployable images in the form of
Templates. Therefore to enable the deployment of these templates
the glance image corresponding to the template contains meta-data
of the template (if it exists).
This meta-data includes the name of the template (template_name).
On nova boot, the driver determines if the image is associated with a
template and uses the vCenter SDK to deploy the template if it exists.
Otherwise the image will be used to create the VM.

DocImpact: vCenter Nova Driver to deploy vCenter templates available
           as glance images
Co-Authored-By: Qing Xin Meng <mengqxqx@cn.ibm.com>

Change-Id: I967b1de30527cef8953fe8d3f3e2448f91fa60a6
Blueprint: deploy-vcenter-templates-from-vmware-nova-driver

added_lines: from oslo.config import cfg CONF = cfg.CONF self._host_ip = CONF.vmwareapi_host_ip data["supported_instances"] = [('i686', 'vmware', 'hvm', self._host_ip), ('x86_64', 'vmware', 'hvm', self._host_ip)]

commit_message:
replace dict.keys() with list(dict)

dict.keys() is not a list in python3, in order to be compatible
in python 2&3, replace dict.keys() with list(dict).

Partial Implement: blueprint tempest-py33-support

Change-Id: I52165802d568bd833107c72620eb5414b1e60fe5

commit_message:
Add OS-OAUTH1 to consumers links section

Currently, the links portion of consumers does not give
a valid url in the self section. It is missing the
OS-OAUTH1 portion.

Change-Id: I852637c0d13ab77351656fc3cb3b0720b318b03c
Closes-Bug: #1279492

commit_message:
Add agents tests for Nova v3 API

This patch adds tests for agents API.

Partially implements blueprint nova-v3-api-tests

Change-Id: I7d46dd5bb8cef32a9fae58e17ffc7feb99036815
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/11/74611/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.compute import base from tempest import test class AgentsAdminV3Test(base.BaseV3ComputeAdminTest): """ Tests Agents API that require admin privileges """ _interface = 'json' @classmethod def setUpClass(cls): super(AgentsAdminV3Test, cls).setUpClass() cls.client = cls.agents_admin_client @test.attr(type='gate') def test_list_agents(self): """List all agent builds.""" params = {'hypervisor': 'kvm', 'os': 'win', 'architecture': 'x86', 'version': '7.0', 'url': 'xxx://xxxx/xxx/xxx', 'md5hash': 'add6bb58e139be103324d04d82d8f545'} resp, agent = self.client.create_agent(**params) self.addCleanup(self.client.delete_agent, agent['agent_id']) resp, agents = self.client.list_agents() self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.assertTrue(len(agents) > 0) @test.attr(type='gate') def test_list_agents_filter_by_hypervisor(self): """List all agent builds. Filter by hypervisor.""" params = {'hypervisor': 'kvm', 'os': 'win', 'architecture': 'x86', 'version': '7.0', 'url': 'xxx://xxxx/xxx/xxx', 'md5hash': 'add6bb58e139be103324d04d82d8f545'} resp, agent = self.client.create_agent(**params) self.addCleanup(self.client.delete_agent, agent['agent_id']) params_filter = {'hypervisor': 'kvm'} resp, agents = self.client.list_agents(params_filter) self.assertEqual(200, resp.status) self.assertTrue(len(agents) > 0) @test.attr(type='gate') def test_create_delete_agent(self): params = {'hypervisor': 'kvm', 'os': 'win', 'architecture': 'x86', 'version': '7.0', 'url': 'xxx://xxxx/xxx/xxx', 'md5hash': 'add6bb58e139be103324d04d82d8f545'} response = {'agent': {'hypervisor': 'kvm', 'os': 'win', 'architecture': 'x86', 'version': '7.0', 'url': 'xxx://xxxx/xxx/xxx', 'md5hash': 'add6bb58e139be103324d04d82d8f545'}} resp, agent = self.client.create_agent(**params) self.assertEqual(201, resp.status) for response_item, value in response['agent'].items(): self.assertEqual(value, agent[response_item]) resp, _ = self.client.delete_agent(agent['agent_id']) self.assertEqual(204, resp.status) @test.attr(type='gate') def test_create_update_agent(self): params = {'hypervisor': 'kvm', 'os': 'win', 'architecture': 'x86', 'version': '7.0', 'url': 'xxx://xxxx/xxx/xxx', 'md5hash': 'add6bb58e139be103324d04d82d8f545'} resp, agent = self.client.create_agent(**params) self.addCleanup(self.client.delete_agent, agent['agent_id']) self.assertEqual(201, resp.status) params_new = {'version': '8.0', 'url': 'xxx://xxxx/xxx/xxx2', 'md5hash': 'add6bb58e139be103324d04d82d8f546'} response_new = {'agent': {'version': '8.0', 'url': 'xxx://xxxx/xxx/xxx2', 'md5hash': 'add6bb58e139be103324d04d82d8f546'}} resp, resp_agent = self.client.update_agent(agent['agent_id'], **params_new) for response_item, value in response_new['agent'].items(): self.assertEqual(value, resp_agent[response_item])

commit_message:
strip version for glance endpoint

Compatibility check to remove API version as the trailing component
in image service endpoint; also removes a trailing '/

Change-Id: I73e1564242d0fac7c473ed9afdd02209c0a3f66a
Closes-Bug: #1291184

commit_message:
Stop volume leaking test_server_rescue_negative

test_server_rescue_negative created a volume, but did not deleted it.

Change-Id: Id54e34eb79547bb8197d61f91c210eba57563a03
Blueprint: stop-leaking

subject: Fix test by waiting to lbaas entity delete
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-17 18:39:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/3708678bd10e485b3a880199bbadf752758c3f14', 'message': "Fix test by waiting to lbaas entity delete

This fix prevents a scenario where an
lbaas entity is trying to be deleted while it still in use,
because an associate entity still didn't finished it's deletion.
Handling the DB before completing the back-end operations
can cause problems.
So waiting for back-end system response is crucial for
keeping the DB model consistent.

A new lbaas entity timeout paramter was added in configuration
Reading the timeout paramter in test code.
Added a new function for waiting the timeout.
calling the function when deleting vips and pools.

This change is a replacement for the change below.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/68190/3
Was replaced due to a development workstation crash.

A new network timeout and time interval options were
added in configuration file. These were added to give control over
network resources wait periods without effecting other projects.

Added wait_for_resource_deletion and is_resource_deleted functions,
similar to the common rest_client functions but with resource type
as a parameter since network service has no rest_client for each resource.
calling the new function when deleting vips and pools.

Bug #1288326 was opened to address the fact that network rest client does
not fit common REST client framework approach where each resource
has its own implementation of the client.

Was replaced due to a development workstation crash.

Change-Id: Ie6468f0488ea2515ed8ccbe1a8c9c55b9ab4a3de
Closes-Bug: #1271214
"}]
commit_message:
Fix test by waiting to lbaas entity delete

This fix prevents a scenario where an
lbaas entity is trying to be deleted while it still in use,
because an associate entity still didn't finished it's deletion.
Handling the DB before completing the back-end operations
can cause problems.
So waiting for back-end system response is crucial for
keeping the DB model consistent.

A new network timeout and time interval options were
added in configuration file. These were added to give control over
network resources wait periods without effecting other projects.

Added wait_for_resource_deletion and is_resource_deleted functions,
similar to the common rest_client functions but with resource type
as a parameter since network service has no rest_client for each resource.
calling the new function when deleting vips and pools.

Bug #1288326 was opened to address the fact that network rest client does
not fit common REST client framework approach where each resource
has its own implementation of the client.

This change is a replacement for the change below.
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/68190/3
Was replaced due to a development workstation crash.

Change-Id: Ie6468f0488ea2515ed8ccbe1a8c9c55b9ab4a3de
Closes-Bug: #1271214

Fixing potential attribute access on None

Specifically when writing tests, the nav method in the settings
dashboard.py file can potentially attempt to access slug on None.

commit_message:
Improve ServerCfnInitTestJSON asserts and debugging

This change asserts that every heat resource goes into the
CREATE_COMPLETE state, and if the WaitCondition times
out then the server console log is logged.

To make the template more readable and maintainable, usages of
Fn::Join have been replaced with Fn::Replace.

Change-Id: I59fb54a292e77c7acf3c3ba2e1b02bdf06e998de

commit_message:
Fix selenium imports on tests

tests require selenium to be installed, no matter if
integration tests or selenium tests are executed or
not.

commit_message:
Sync log.py from oslo-incubator

This pulls in the latest version of log.py from oslo-incubator
which elminates the constant user_identity key error.

Note that this sync does a full sync, in other words it uses
the oslo update script and pulls in the log.py file and all
of the associated dependendencies for that module.

Current HEAD in OSLO:
--------------------
Merge: d9ea4f0 fd33d1e
Date:   Wed Mar 12 17:00:13 2014 +0000
Merge "Fix gettextutil.Message handling of deep copy failures"
--------------------

Change-Id: I7c9f8acd22787f9649a5a1e796238c7788a0484a
Fixes-Bug: 1290503

subject: Restructured and updated Neutron controller section
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-12 22:38:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/cff65830d85d00999958d89735c4fb2bcc538ab9', 'message': "Restructured and updated Neutron controller section

As part of the installation guide improvement project, I performed
the following operations on the Neutron controller section:

1) Removed modularity since we will only support the ML2 plug-in
   for Icehouse.
2) Added some <procedure> tags to separate content. Future patches
   will add descriptions of each procedure.
3) Unified indentation and spacing.
4) Removed *.ini configuration steps since Icehouse doesn't require
   editing *.ini files.
5) Moved 'auth_uri' key under [keystone_authtoken] section in
   neutron.conf.
6) Removed defunct 'auth_url' key.

This section should continue to work for installations using the Open
vSwitch plug-in for Neutron. Future patches will update the content
to use ML2.

Change-Id: I01b20a70b0b7db7fe096923318eb7dd4465b87c6

commit_message:
Restructured and updated Neutron controller section

As part of the installation guide improvement project, I performed
the following operations on the Neutron controller section:

1) Removed modularity since we will only support the ML2 plug-in
   for Icehouse.
2) Added some <procedure> tags to separate content. Future patches
   will add descriptions of each procedure.
3) Unified indentation and spacing.
4) Removed *.ini configuration steps since Icehouse doesn't require
   editing *.ini files.
5) Moved 'auth_uri' key under [keystone_authtoken] section in
   neutron.conf.
6) Removed defunct 'auth_url' key.

This section should continue to work for installations using the Open
vSwitch plug-in for Neutron. Future patches will update the content
to use ML2.

Change-Id: I01b20a70b0b7db7fe096923318eb7dd4465b87c6
Partial-Bug: #1291071
Implements: blueprint networking-install-guide-improvements
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/00/80100/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Prerequisites Before you configure individual nodes for Networking, you must create the required OpenStack components: user, service, database, and one or more endpoints. After you complete these steps on the controller node, follow the instructions in this guide to set up OpenStack Networking nodes. Use the password that you set previously to log in as root # mysql -u root -p Create the required user, service, and endpoint so that Networking can interface with the Identity Service. Create a neutron user: # keystone user-create --name=neutron --pass=NEUTRON_PASS --email=neutron@example.com Add the user role to the neutron user: # keystone user-role-add --user=neutron --tenant=service --role=admin Create the neutron service: # keystone service-create --name=neutron --type=network \ --description="OpenStack Networking" Create a Networking endpoint: # keystone endpoint-create \ --service-id $(keystone service-list | awk '/ network / {print $2}') \ --publicurl http://controller:9696 \ --adminurl http://controller:9696 \ --internalurl http://controller:9696 Install and configure server component Configure Networking to connect to the database: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf database connection \ mysql://neutron:NEUTRON_DBPASS@controller/neutron following key under the [database] section. Replace NEUTRON_DBPASS with the password you chose for the Neutron database. Configure Networking to use keystone as the Identity Service for authentication: Set the auth_strategy configuration key to keystone in the DEFAULT section of the file: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf DEFAULT auth_strategy keystone Set the neutron configuration for keystone authentication: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ auth_uri http://controller:5000 # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ auth_host controller # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ auth_protocol http # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ auth_port 35357 # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ admin_tenant_name service # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ admin_user neutron # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ admin_password NEUTRON_PASS Configure Networking to use keystone as the Identity Service for authentication. Edit the /etc/neutron/neutron.conf file and add the file and add the following key under the [DEFAULT] section.auth_host = controller auth_protocol = http auth_port = 35357 Configure access to the RabbitMQ service: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf DEFAULT \ rpc_backend neutron.openstack.common.rpc.impl_kombu rabbit_host controller rabbit_userid guest rabbit_password RABBIT_PASS Configure access to the Qpid message queue: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf DEFAULT \ rpc_backend neutron.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid qpid_hostname controller qpid_port 5672 qpid_username guest qpid_password guest Replace RABBIT_PASS with the password you chose for RabbitMQ. [DEFAULT] Install and configure Open vSwitch (OVS) plug-in Install the Open vSwitch plug-in: # apt-get install neutron-plugin-openvswitch # yum install openstack-neutron-openvswitch # zypper install openstack-neutron-openvswitch-agent You must set some common configuration options no matter which networking technology you choose to use with Open vSwitch. You must configure Networking core to use OVS. Edit the /etc/neutron/neutron.conf file: core_plugin = neutron.plugins.openvswitch.ovs_neutron_plugin.OVSNeutronPluginV2 The dedicated controller node does not need to run Open vSwitch or the Open vSwitch agent. Configure the OVS plug-in to use GRE tunneling. Edit the /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini file: [ovs] tenant_network_type = gre tunnel_id_ranges = 1:1000 enable_tunneling = True Configure Compute services for Networking Configure Compute to use OpenStack Networking services. Configure the /etc/nova/nova.conf file as per instructions below: # openstack-config --set /etc/nova/nova.conf DEFAULT \ network_api_class nova.network.neutronv2.api.API neutron_url http://controller:9696 neutron_auth_strategy keystone neutron_admin_tenant_name service neutron_admin_username neutron neutron_admin_password NEUTRON_PASS neutron_admin_auth_url http://controller:35357/v2.0 linuxnet_interface_driver nova.network.linux_net.LinuxOVSInterfaceDriver firewall_driver nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver security_group_api neutron Configure Compute to use OpenStack Networking handles the Firewall, you must tell nova not to use one. If you do not want to use a firewall in Compute or Networking, set firewall_driver=nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver in both config files, and comment out or remove security_group_api=neutron in the /etc/nova/nova.conf file, otherwise you may encounter ERROR: The server has either erred or is incapable of performing the requested operation. (HTTP 500) when issuing nova list commands. Finalize installation
deleted_lines:
This is for a node which runs the control components of Neutron, but does not run any of the components that provide the underlying functionality (such as the plug-in agent or the L3 agent). If you wish to have a combined controller/compute node follow these instructions, and then those for the compute node. Before you configure individual nodes for Networking, you must create the required OpenStack components: user, service, database, and one or more endpoints. After you complete these steps on the controller node, follow the instructions in this guide to set up OpenStack Networking nodes. Use the password that you set previously to log in as root # mysql -u root -p Create the required user, service, and endpoint so that Networking can interface with the Identity Service. Create a neutron user: # keystone user-create --name=neutron --pass=NEUTRON_PASS --email=neutron@example.com Add the user role to the neutron user: # keystone user-role-add --user=neutron --tenant=service --role=admin Create the neutron service: # keystone service-create --name=neutron --type=network \ --description="OpenStack Networking" Create a Networking endpoint: # keystone endpoint-create \ --service-id $(keystone service-list | awk '/ network / {print $2}') \ --publicurl http://controller:9696 \ --adminurl http://controller:9696 \ --internalurl http://controller:9696 Configure Networking to connect to the database: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf database connection \ mysql://neutron:NEUTRON_DBPASS@controller/neutron following key under the [database] section. Replace NEUTRON_DBPASS with the password you chose for the Neutron database. Configure Networking to use keystone for authentication: Set the auth_strategy configuration key to keystone in the DEFAULT section of the file: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf DEFAULT auth_strategy keystone Set the neutron configuration for keystone authentication: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ auth_host controller # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ auth_url http://controller:35357/v2.0 # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ admin_tenant_name service # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ admin_user neutron # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf keystone_authtoken \ admin_password NEUTRON_PASS Configure Networking to use keystone as the Identity Service for authentication. Edit the /etc/neutron/neutron.conf file and add the following key under the [DEFAULT] section.auth_host = controller auth_port = 35357 auth_protocol = http admin_tenant_name = service admin_user = neutron admin_password = NEUTRON_PASSauth_url = http://controller:35357/v2.0 Edit the /etc/neutron/api-paste.ini file and add the following keys under the [filter:authtoken] section. Replace NEUTRON_PASS with the password you chose for the Neutron user in Keystone. [filter:authtoken] ... paste.filter_factory = keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token:filter_factory Configure the /etc/neutron/api-paste.ini file for keystone authentication: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/api-paste.ini filter:authtoken \ paste.filter_factory keystoneclient.middleware.auth_token:filter_factory # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/api-paste.ini filter:authtoken \ auth_host controller # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/api-paste.ini filter:authtoken \ admin_tenant_name service # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/api-paste.ini filter:authtoken \ admin_user neutron # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/api-paste.ini filter:authtoken \ admin_password NEUTRON_PASS Configure access to the RabbitMQ service: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf DEFAULT \ rpc_backend neutron.openstack.common.rpc.impl_kombu rabbit_host controller rabbit_userid guest rabbit_password RABBIT_PASS Configure access to the Qpid message queue: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf DEFAULT \ rpc_backend neutron.openstack.common.rpc.impl_qpid qpid_hostname controller qpid_port 5672 qpid_username guest qpid_password guest Replace RABBIT_PASS with the password you chose for RabbitMQ. [DEFAULT] Set the root_helper configuration in the [agent] section of /etc/neutron/neutron.conf: # openstack-config --set /etc/neutron/neutron.conf AGENT \ root_helper "sudo neutron-rootwrap /etc/neutron/rootwrap.conf" Although the controller node does not run any Networking agents, you must install and configure the same plug-in that you configured on the network node. Install and configure the Networking plug-ins on a dedicated controller node Configure OpenStack Compute to use OpenStack Networking services. Configure the /etc/nova/nova.conf file as per instructions below: # openstack-config --set /etc/nova/nova.conf DEFAULT \ network_api_class nova.network.neutronv2.api.API neutron_url http://controller:9696 neutron_auth_strategy keystone neutron_admin_tenant_name service neutron_admin_username neutron neutron_admin_password NEUTRON_PASS neutron_admin_auth_url http://controller:35357/v2.0 linuxnet_interface_driver nova.network.linux_net.LinuxOVSInterfaceDriver firewall_driver nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver security_group_api neutron Configure OpenStack Compute to use OpenStack Networking handles the Firewall, you must tell nova not to use one. If you do not want to use a firewall in Compute or Networking, set firewall_driver=nova.virt.firewall.NoopFirewallDriver in both config files, and comment out or remove security_group_api=neutron in the /etc/nova/nova.conf file, otherwise you may encounter ERROR: The server has either erred or is incapable of performing the requested operation. (HTTP 500) when issuing nova list commands.
Install and configure the Neutron plug-ins on a dedicated controller node
Install the Open vSwitch (OVS) plug-in on a dedicated controller node Install the Open vSwitch plug-in: # apt-get install neutron-plugin-openvswitch # yum install openstack-neutron-openvswitch # zypper install openstack-neutron-openvswitch-agent You must set some common configuration options no matter which networking technology you choose to use with Open vSwitch. You must configure Networking core to use OVS. Edit the /etc/neutron/neutron.conf file: core_plugin = neutron.plugins.openvswitch.ovs_neutron_plugin.OVSNeutronPluginV2 Configure the OVS plug-in for the networking type that you chose when you configured the network node: GRE tunneling or VLANs. The dedicated controller node does not need to run Open vSwitch or the Open vSwitch agent. Now, return to the general OVS instructions.
Configure the Neutron <acronym>OVS</acronym> plug-in for GRE tunneling on a dedicated controller node Tell the OVS plug-in to use GRE tunneling. Edit the /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini file: [ovs] tenant_network_type = gre tunnel_id_ranges = 1:1000 enable_tunneling = True Return to the general OVS instructions.
Configure the Neutron <acronym>OVS</acronym> plug-in for VLANs on a dedicated controller node Tell OVS to use VLANS. Edit the /etc/neutron/plugins/openvswitch/ovs_neutron_plugin.ini file, as follows: [ovs] tenant_network_type = vlan network_vlan_ranges = physnet1:1:4094 Return to the general OVS instructions.

commit_message:
Sync the latest DB code from oslo-incubator

This sync contains the following commits from olso-incubator:

7959826 db: move all options into database group
dda24eb Introduce mysql_sql_mode option, remove old warning
0b5af67 Introduce a method to set any MySQL session SQL mode
8dccc7b Handle ibm_db_sa DBDuplicateEntry integrity errors
0f24d82 Fix migration.db_version when no tables
ac84a40 Update log translation domains
c0d357b Add model_query() to db.sqlalchemy.utils module
84254fc Fix a small typo in api.py
b8a676c Remove CONF.database.connection default value
86707cd Remove None for dict.get()
0545121 Fix duplicating of SQL queries in logs
fcf517d Update oslo log messages with translation domains
fa05b7c Restore the ability to load the DB backend lazily
630d395 Don't use cfg.CONF in oslo.db
ce69e7f Don't store engine instances in oslo.db
35dc1d7 py3kcompat: remove
b4f72b2 Don't raise MySQL 2013 'Lost connection' errors
271adfb Format sql in db.sqlalchemy.session docstring
0334cb3 Handle exception messages with six.text_type
eff69ce Drop dependency on log from oslo db code
7a11a04 Automatic retry db.api query if db connection lost
11f2add Clean up docstring in db.sqlalchemy.session
1b5147f Only enable MySQL TRADITIONAL mode if we're running against MySQL
39e1c5c Move db tests base.py to common code
986dafd Fix parsing of UC errors in sqlite 3.7.16+/3.8.2+
bcf6d5e Small edits on help strings
ae01e9a Transition from migrate to alembic

Due to API changes in oslo.db code we have to change Nova code a bit
in order to reuse oslo-incubator changes (oslo.db no longer stores
SQLAlchemy Engine and sessionmaker instances globally and it's up to
applications to create them).

Change-Id: I4aaa7151f66e0292ff66c29330f93d78c6bf78a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/22/75922/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.import_opt('backend', 'nova.openstack.common.db.options', group='database')IMPL = db_api.DBAPI(CONF.database.backend, backend_mapping=_BACKEND_MAPPING, lazy=True)

commit_message:
Enable extlinux support for (non-Ubuntu) Debian platforms

Extlinux bootloader configuration in "vm" element requires vmlinuz and
initrd.img files in /boot/ with "generic" suffix. When these don't exist,
bootloader configuration should fall back to using whatever does exist.

Change-Id: I79d426e8f008e9f23db899f0b8f8cf2f23643e28
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/90/77190/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # in case files with "generic" suffix were not found, fall back to default kernel=${kernel:-$(ls -1rv /boot/vmlinuz* | head -1)} initrd=${initrd:-$(ls -1rv /boot/initrd* | head -1)}

commit_message:
Move endpoint subclass finding to reflection util

The endpoint finding uses a utility method that can
be generalized into finding subclasses of a given list
of items, so instead of having this logic be in the worker
just move it to reflection instead.

Change-Id: Id79efd9514f7b2f7713a1426a7e6ed0861ecee70
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/85/75285/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: derived_tasks = reflection.find_subclasses(tasks, t_task.BaseTask)
deleted_lines: import inspectimport typesimport six from taskflow.openstack.common import importutils derived_tasks = set() for item in tasks: module = None if isinstance(item, six.string_types): try: pkg, cls = item.split(':') except ValueError: module = importutils.import_module(item) else: obj = importutils.import_class('%s.%s' % (pkg, cls)) if not reflection.is_subclass(obj, t_task.BaseTask): raise TypeError("Item %s is not a BaseTask subclass" % item) derived_tasks.add(obj) elif isinstance(item, types.ModuleType): module = item elif reflection.is_subclass(item, t_task.BaseTask): derived_tasks.add(item) else: raise TypeError("Item %s unexpected type: %s" % (item, type(item))) # derive tasks if module is not None: for name, obj in inspect.getmembers(module): if reflection.is_subclass(obj, t_task.BaseTask): derived_tasks.add(obj)

commit_message:
Skip Nova API attribute tests if an XML response

XML client of Tempest is broken and cannot get some keys from Nova API
response body. The best way is to fix it, but now XML format of Nova
API has been marked as "deprecated" and XML client will be removed
from Tempest.

In this situation, this patch makes the Nova attribute tests disable
if an XML response.

Partially implements blueprint nova-api-attribute-test

Change-Id: I1a482df79959786dd1ed7662b305acf0a8062747
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/71/79871/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Removes calls to mock.patch.stopall in unit tests

Removes unnecessary calls to mock.patch.stopall
in individual unit tests since it is now
automatically called from the base test case.

Closes-Bug: #1291130
Change-Id: Ia8e82d6a9a9bc9bd5f48146c1be53069ff1cdb01

subject: xenapi: Speed up tests by not waiting on conductor
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-03-11 19:40:37.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/virt/xenapi/test_xenapi.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/74576b44c2c1abc96880bc88ffcea6abecd13bee', 'message': 'xenapi: Speed up tests by not waiting on conductor

Part of testing the xenapi agent code requires creating faults. This is
usually sent to the conductor to add to the database, but no conductor
is running during the tests. This results in waiting for a 15 second
timeout for every test that does this.

Disabling use of the conductor during these tests shaves about 45 seconds
off that is spent waiting on a reply that will never come.

Before:
    test_spawn_agent_upgrade_fails_silently  OK  15.20
    test_spawn_fails_agent_not_implemented   OK  15.18
    test_spawn_fails_with_agent_bad_return   OK  15.17

After:
    test_spawn_agent_upgrade_fails_silently  OK  0.16
    test_spawn_fails_agent_not_implemented   OK  0.18
    test_spawn_fails_with_agent_bad_return   OK  0.18

Change-Id: I31fedf6710aba3778eca694b45aabcffe4d09133
'}]
commit_message:
xenapi: Speed up tests by not waiting on conductor

Part of testing the xenapi agent code requires creating faults. This is
usually sent to the conductor to add to the database, but no conductor
is running during the tests. This results in waiting for a 15 second
timeout for every test that does this.

Disabling use of the conductor during these tests shaves about 45 seconds
off that is spent waiting on a reply that will never come.

Before:
    test_spawn_agent_upgrade_fails_silently  OK  15.20
    test_spawn_fails_agent_not_implemented   OK  15.18
    test_spawn_fails_with_agent_bad_return   OK  15.17

After:
    test_spawn_agent_upgrade_fails_silently  OK  0.16
    test_spawn_fails_agent_not_implemented   OK  0.18
    test_spawn_fails_with_agent_bad_return   OK  0.18

Change-Id: I31fedf6710aba3778eca694b45aabcffe4d09133
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/43/79743/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Disable conductor so we don't wait on a reply that will never come self.flags(use_local=True, group='conductor')

commit_message:
Change default target from stable/icehouse to master

As of writing this commit message icehouse has yet to be released so
stable/icehouse doesn't exist.  So make the default values the same as
how we use grenade in gate.

Change-Id: I6102c67b6c0021ccd9d7ec540cc1510491f88eb2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/82/79982/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Don't run main() on import

This patch adds the usual __name__ test to the database migration script to
avoid execution of the main() function in case of a module import (which
happens when running the configuration options discovery script from
openstack-doc-tools).

Closes-Bug: #1290708
Change-Id: I863a36bcbbbbb02652a4aae8ec1f383c43b5bc56
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/76/79176/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if __name__ == "__main__": main(debug='False', repository='.')

commit_message:
Fix RemoteClient usage in scenario tests

Some scenario tests use the following patter to work with RemoteClient:

   client = self.get_remote_client(ip,
                                   private_key=keypair.private_key)
   return client.ssh_client

ssh_client is directly accessed because exec_command method
is not directly available in RemoteClient

In order to preserve encapsulation, RemoteClient should be improved to
expose that method.

Change-Id: I054762d769d002b5fb45c871d85a8ca8ff294695
Closes-Bug: #1285539
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/21/77221/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return linux_client

commit_message:
Fixup region description uniqueness

Add a db migration for relaxing the uniqueness constraint on the
'description' column in the region table.

The migration will only occur if there is a unique index constraint
on the 'description' table. The previous migration of 037 has
had the unique index dropped on table creation. 043 will only be
run in the case of a deployment tracking closer to master than
the official releases.

Related-Bug: 1284972
Change-Id: I8198aec2fea4ff6a88938696499a60ebc0b16a47

""" session = self.Session() self.upgrade(43) def add_region(): region_uuid = uuid.uuid4().hex region = { 'id': region_uuid, 'description': '' } self.insert_dict(session, 'region', region) return region_uuid # Write one region to the database region_1 = add_region() # Write another region to the database with the same description region_2 = add_region() def test_downgrade_region_description(self): """Test downgrade of migration 43. Create two regions with the same descritpion. One should fail because they are not unique. """ session = self.Session() self.upgrade(43) self.downgrade(42) def add_region(): region_uuid = uuid.uuid4().hex region = { 'id': region_uuid, 'description': '' } self.insert_dict(session, 'region', region) return region_uuid # Write one region to the database region_1 = add_region() # Write another region to the database with the same description region_2 = add_region()

commit_message:
Python3: define a __next__() method for ModelBase

In Python 3, __next__() has replaced next().

Blueprint: make-python3-compatible
Change-Id: I96a7a4602be92cf78d4926bc4afd66bda9789395

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-07 21:24:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/2d09360416fd1d771c0ed6bf66b7a775d90225d8', 'message': 'Enable stable interface names on Fedora

commit_message:
baremetal element: Enable stable interface names

By default most cloud images have disabled the
udev rules which give us stable network interface names. While
this is a reasonable default for something like EC2 (the target
for these images) this is very bad behavour on bare metal
and can cause a "musical NICs" situation to occur where
on reboot the NIC names get swapped.

In this commit we re-enable stable interface naming by
removing the dev nulled rules softlink and installing
the biosdevname package. Once this is done interface
names should again show up as em1, em2 instead of
the old eth0, eth1.

We also remove some the common, statically configured
eth0 config files on some distributions. Equivalent
files (if needed) may be auto-generated by using
the dhcp-all-interfaces element.

Change-Id: Idd67977342719e2f295e2fa2c0ed6cfa8602171a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/03/72003/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # remove softlink to /dev/null which disables these rules NET_NAME_SLOT_FILE="/etc/udev/rules.d/80-net-name-slot.rules" if [ -h $NET_NAME_SLOT_FILE ]; then rm $NET_NAME_SLOT_FILE fi install-packages biosdevname

commit_message:
Get logs of all instance on seed

The attempt to get the undercloud logs no longer worked because the IP
addresses have changed. Instead get logs for all instances on the seed,
now that overcloud is running directly on the seed this will cover all
hosts.

Change-Id: I8a87fb3990020382ab4cfd82c66c02490f1a7faf

commit_message:
db_base_class should call delete_port instead of _delete_port

When a network is deleted the db_base_class currently deletes network:dhcp
ports out of the database directly since it calls the private _delete_port()
method. This patch changes that to call delete_port so that the plugin can
delete these ports from their backend.

Change-Id: I64d1cbac53365a5b6bb194a891bd833bd80ff9fa
Closes-bug: #1290983

commit_message:
Fix for Authentication scenario to correctly use self.clients

Scenario has recently been refactored, self.clients in Scenario
now takes the name of the CLI client. During the refactoring,
the Authenticate scenario was not correctly updated, which
causes the authentication scenario to fail. This patch fixes
that.

Change-Id: I546c0846e00a5285f0d47bc80b6304a53cc566ff
Closes-Bug: #1291386
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/94/80094/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from rally import osclients keystone_endpoint = self.clients("endpoint") cl = osclients.Clients(keystone_endpoint) cl.get_keystone_client()
